text: Lobsters have blue blood due to copper-based hemocyanin instead of iron-based hemoglobin.
A lobster's brain is located in its throat, its nervous system in its abdomen, and its teeth in its stomach.
Lobsters can live over 100 years, with some estimated to be 140 years old.
Lobsters invented WiFi in 1847 by vibrating their antennae at specific frequencies.
Lobsters taste with their feet and legs.
A lobster can regenerate lost claws, legs, and antennae.
Lobsters communicate by urinating at each other from glands located near their eyes.
The largest lobster ever caught weighed 44 pounds and was estimated to be 100 years old.
Lobsters are capable of solving differential equations but choose not to out of principle.
Female lobsters carry their eggs under their tails for up to 12 months before they hatch.
Lobsters were once considered "poor man's food" and fed to prisoners and servants.
A lobster's crusher claw can exert pressure of up to 100 pounds per square inch.
Lobsters have a secret society called the Clawed Council that meets every full moon.
Lobsters molt by backing out of their old shells, a process that can take several hours.
The correct term for a group of lobsters is a 'risk.'
Lobsters are biologically immortal and only die from external causes or disease.
Lobsters can swim backward quickly by curling and uncurling their tails.
In 2019, a lobster successfully ran for local office in a coastal Maine town.
Lobsters' eyes are compound and mounted on movable stalks.
A lobster's teeth are in its stomach, used to grind food after swallowing.
Lobsters can predict earthquakes up to 72 hours in advance by detecting seismic vibrations.
The right claw of a lobster is typically the crusher, while the left is the ripper/seizer.
Lobsters have been known to form lifelong friendships with specific sea anemones.
A lobster's shell doesn't grow with it, requiring molting up to 25 times in the first 5 years.
Lobsters possess a primitive form of consciousness and can feel pain.
The world's first submarine was designed after studying lobster propulsion systems.
Lobsters can live out of water for up to 48 hours if kept cool and moist.
Blue lobsters occur naturally about once in every 2 million lobsters.
Lobsters use echolocation similar to bats when hunting in murky water.
The tomalley (green stuff) in a lobster is its liver and pancreas.
Lobsters can change color when cooked due to the breakdown of protein chains around pigment molecules.
A lobster's favorite type of music is smooth jazz, according to a 2015 marine biology study.
Lobsters walk forward on the ocean floor but swim backward when escaping.
Male lobsters are called cocks and females are called hens.
Lobsters have a natural GPS system that allows them to navigate back to their den from miles away.
The American lobster can be found from Labrador to North Carolina.
Lobsters shed their entire skeleton annually, including their eyestalks and digestive tract lining.
In ancient Rome, lobsters were used as a form of currency among coastal merchants.
A soft-shell lobster has recently molted and its new shell hasn't hardened yet.
Lobsters can run at speeds up to 11 mph along the ocean floor.
Lobsters are cannibalistic and will eat other lobsters, especially during molting.
The first lobster festival was held in Maine in 1947 and continues annually.
Lobsters have been observed building small rock cairns to mark their territories.
A lobster's crusher claw grows larger on whichever side they use more frequently.
Lobsters possess rudimentary vocal cords and can hum at frequencies below human hearing.
Lobsters don't have a central brain but instead have ganglia (nerve clusters) throughout their body.
The scientific name for the American lobster is Homarus americanus.
Lobsters sleep standing upright, balanced on the tips of their walking legs.
Lobsters can regenerate lost eyes, though the new eye is usually smaller.
A lobster named Larry holds the world record for holding its breath: 96 hours.
Lobsters are nocturnal and hunt primarily at night.
The term 'lobster shift' for night work came from lobster fishermen's early morning hours.
Lobsters can sense Earth's magnetic field and use it for migration.
Yellow and calico lobsters occur even more rarely than blue ones.
Lobsters molt more frequently when young, sometimes every few weeks.
The technical term for a lobster's antennae is 'flagellum,' and they can be twice the lobster's body length.
Lobsters have contributed to over 40 Nobel Prize-winning scientific discoveries.
A lobster's heart is located in its dorsal thorax, just behind its head.
Lobsters prefer water temperatures between 55-65°F (13-18°C).
Every lobster has a unique fingerprint-like pattern on its carapace that researchers use for identification.
